metadata.title: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
description: Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) is a chronic, functional GI disorder associated with recurrent abdominal pain and altered bowel habits.(1,9) IBS affects 7% to 21% of the general population in developed nations and the global prevalence averages about 11%, making it one of the most common GI disorders(6,12)

Patients are typically categorized by IBS subtype according to their usual stool consistency (i.e., diarrhea predominant [IBS-D], constipation predominant [IBS-C],  or mixed [IBS-M]),  and treated accordingly. The predominant subtype may change over time.(2) Reduced health-related  QOL is a major problem for patients with IBS(13)
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. No specific special agencies, issues, or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: The diagnosis relies mainly on symptoms listed in the Rome II process and the U.S. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guidelines (rather than objective biomarkers) and exclusion of atypical features such as the following: symptom onset after age 50 years, unexplained weight loss, family history of selected organic gastrointestinal diseases, evidence of GI blood loss, unexplained iron-deficiency  anemia, and abnormal physical examination(12)

Diagnostic criteria based on the NICE guideline include the following:(2) –Abdominal pain or discomfort relieved by defecation or associated with altered bowel movement frequency or stool consistency. This should be accompanied by at least 2 of the following 4 symptoms: -Altered stool passage (straining, urgency, incomplete evacuation) -Abdominal bloating (more common in women than men), distension, tension, or hardness -Symptoms are made worse by eating -Passage of mucus  –Healthcare providers should consider assessment for IBS if the patient reports having experienced any of the following for a minimum of 6 months: -Abdominal pain -Bloating -Change in bowel movement habits
Pattern of abdominal pain associated with IBS: chronic duration, intermittent pain, pain relief with defecation or with passing of flatus
Abdominal distension: bloating and distension are not the same; bloating is a subjective feeling whereas distension can be measured
Reduced QOL(13) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Red flag complications that warrant stopping the evaluation and referring the patient back to physician(2) –Anemia –Enlarged lymph nodes –Fever –Abdominal or rectal masses –Abnormal physical examination

causes: Psychological factors have not been shown to cause or influence the onset of IBS; however, they may play a role in thepersistence and perceived severity of abdominal symptoms

The association between digestive diseases and psychological disorders indicates a relationship between the brain andintestine, referred to as the brain-gut  axis. The amygdala, hippocampus, and prefrontal cortex may regulate the function ofthe intestine in conjunction with emotion(10)
pathogenesis: Individuals with IBS may be characterized as having abnormalities of gut motility, visceral sensation, brain-gut  interaction,and psychosocial distress(1)

Authors of a 2015 systematic review of 22 studies (N = 7,106 patients) found that the best available biomarkers of havingIBS (i.e., fecal calprotectin and intestinal permeability) were no better at diagnosing IBS than psychological markers(14)

Authors of a cross-sectional  study that surveyed a cohort (N = 208) of IBS patients in Norway found that the severity ofsymptoms was of minor clinical importance in determining QOL. They recommended that treatment should focus more onimproving QOL than on relieving IBS symptoms(13)
risk factors: Females are 1.67 times more likely to experience IBS compared to males (29)

Acute infectious gastroenteritis can increase the risk of IBS–Authors of a cohort study of primary-care  patients (N = 2,428) in the Netherlands found that patients with a history ofgastroenteritis had an increased risk of having IBS diagnosed within 5 years. IBS was diagnosed in 1.2% of patients witha positive history in a 1-year  period compared to 0.3% of the reference group. The 1-year  relative risk was 4.85 and the5-year  relative risk was 5.40(9)
IBS and functional constipation may be highly prevalent in those in the nursing field who also present with poor sleep (25)
Preschoolers with a history of allergic diseases have an increased risk of developing IBS (28)

overall contraindications precautions: All patients should be asked if they have any of the following red flag indicators and, if so, referred back to physician:(2) Unintentional and unexplained weight loss Rectal bleeding/blood in stool (hematochezia) A family history of colorectal disease, celiac disease, or inflammatory bowel disease A family history of ovarian cancer Fever in conjunction with abdominal pain Pain related to menstruation A change in bowel habits to looser and/or more frequent stools, persisting for more than 6 weeks, in a person over the age of 60 years
It is important to always respect the patient’s perceived level of discomfort/pain and proceed with the evaluation and treatment as indicated
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under  Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Red flag complications that warrant stopping the evaluation and referring the patient back to physician(2) –Anemia –Enlarged lymph nodes –Fever –Abdominal or rectal masses –Abnormal physical examination

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Unknown cause. Document date of onset and IBS subtype (i.e., C, D, or M). Have symptoms progressed, stabilized, or changed recently? Are usual ADLs adversely affected? What is the reason for referral?

course of treatment.medical management: Traditional medical management involves dietary modification and multiple pharmacological agents according to symptoms(2) Document current prescribed interventions, including medications, general dietary advice, prescribed activity, psychological counseling, and complementary/alternative therapy (e.g., probiotics such as lactic acid bacteria). Are the interventions effective? A dual-coated  probiotic may be a treatment option for improving overall discomfort in patients with diarrheapredominant  IBS (22) Patients who develop refractory IBS (i.e., do not respond to pharmacological interventions after 12 months) may benefit from psychotherapeutic and/or complementary/alternative treatments, according to the NICE guidelines(2)
course of treatment.medications: Laxative, stool softener, lubiprostone (Amitiza) for IBS-C Antidiarrheal such as loperamide hydrochloride (Imodium) for IBS-DFDA-approved  only for women with severe IBS-D Antispasmodic (i.e., anticholinergic agent) such as alverine citrate or peppermint oil for abdominal cramps Antidepressant such as fluoxetine (Prozac)antiemetic for persistent IBS-specific  symptoms Nonabsorptive antibiotic such as rifaximin for modulation of GI microflora Probiotics A 4-week  trial with combination probiotics taken twice a day was safe and effective at reducing patients’ general symptoms of IBS(7) In an RCT conducted in Iran with 97 adult patients, 85% of the subjects in the multi-strain probiotic group reported a reduction in bloating and pain compared to 47% of the subjects in the control group Partially hydrolyzed guar gum (PHGG) may provide symptom relief for patients with IBS-C(18) The American Gastroenterological Association (AGA) Guideline on the Pharmacological Management of Irritable(20) IBS-C   linaclotide is strongly recommended (high-quality  evidence), lubiprostone is conditionally recommended (moderatequality evidence), and polyethylene glycol (PEG) laxatives are conditionally recommended (lowquality evidence) IBS-D   rifaximin and alosetron are conditionally recommended (moderate-quality evidence) and loperamide is conditionally recommended (verylow-quality  evidence) For general IBS  tricyclic antidepressants and antispasmodics are conditionally recommended (low-quality evidence) The guideline recommends against the use of SSRIs (low-quality  evidence)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Usual diagnostic tests for this condition are the following:(2)
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or plasma viscosity
Antibody testing for celiac disease (i.e., endomysial antibodies or tissue transglutaminase)
Hydrogen breath test (for lactose intolerance and bacterial overgrowth)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document current use of any alternative/complementary therapies (e.g., probiotics, relaxation therapy, acupuncture, homeopathy) and whether they help Authors of an RCT (N = 94) of patients assigned to homeopathy, supportive listening, or usual care groups in the United Kingdom found a statistically significant improvement in IBS symptoms after 26 weeks in those who received individualized homeopathy compared to the usual care (control) group. 62% of the homeopathy group significantly reduced their severity score on the IBS Severity Scoring System (IBSSSS)  compared to 39% in the supportive listening group and 25% in the control group(11) Authors of a cohort study (n = 51) of adolescent and young adult (1826  years) patients in the United States assigned to Iyengar yoga (2 times per week for 6 weeks) or usual care waitlist  (control) groups found significantly improved IBS symptoms and global functioning in the Iyengar yoga group compared to the control group(15)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has received occupational, physical, or psychological therapy for this condition (or other conditions that may influence therapeutic decision making) and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document dietary triggers (e.g., milk, artificial sweeteners, dieting products, alcohol). Does defecation or passing of flatus relieve discomfort? Is there a feeling of incomplete emptying after defecation? Do symptoms increase with the use of any prescribed or OTC medications?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. In some patients, pain may be well-localized to the lower quadrant or the abdomen while in others the pain location is variable
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms and whether constant vs. intermittent (e.g., bloating with sharp, dull, or aching abdominal discomfort, abdominal distension, bloating, flatulence)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also, document changes in symptoms due to eating habits such as irregular or inadequate meals, fluid intake, fiber intake)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, depression, anxiety, bowel/bladder/ sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document status if patient is receiving treatment for a respiratory condition Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: History of GI infection or dysfunction
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other medical problems, including fibromyalgia, chronic fatigue syndrome, headaches, incontinence, genital pain, psychiatric disorders, diabetes, cancer, heart disease, orthopedic disorders, celiac disease, and food allergies
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs) for comorbidities
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing that may affect treatment choices. The most common coexisting psychological conditions associated with IBS are anxiety, depression, somatization, hypochondria, and symptomrelated  fears. These conditions can contribute to impairment in the patient’s quality of life

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient currently working? If so, describe the job duties. Have symptoms affected patient’s work productivity? What recreational activities, physical exercise, or sports does the patient participate in? What is the frequency of these physical activities? What hobbies or special interests does the patient have? Do symptoms interfere with the patient’s occupation or participation in recreational or competitive sports? How does the patient access his/her community (driving, public transportation?)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Does the patient currently use any assistive or adaptive devices? Typically, these devices are not indicated for patients with IBS unless they have comorbid conditions
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom does the patient live (e.g., family members, caregivers)? Identify if there are any physical barriers to patient’s independence in the home. Number of stairs to enter home? Number of floors in home?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document height, weight, and BMI. Authors of a 2014 systematic review with meta-analysis  found that the frequency of IBS in obese children and adults is variable and depends on the study population. Further studies are needed to determine the association between obesity and IBS(8)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess need for assistive device if gait, balance, and functional mobility is impaired due to coexisting medical conditions
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess standing static and dynamic balance using the Berg Balance Scale. Balance may be impaired if the patient has comorbidities
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess bilateral pedal pulsesAssess dermatomes and myotomes in upper extremity (UE) and lower extremity (LE)Assess basic ADLs and levels of assistance required to safely and independently perform them, as indicated. Use Timed Up and Go (TUG) test and/or Timed Up and Down Stairs (TUDS) test to assess functional limitations, as indicated. May use FIM to assess gross motor ability. Assess ability to get and transfer to the toilet safely and timely, as indicated
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait for any significant deviations, decreased speed, etc. Assess safety with Dynamic Gait Index (DGI)Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity joint mobility for crepitus, contractures, or hypomobility/hypermobility. Use the Paris Stoddard Scale for joint mobilityAssess UE, LE, and trunk for abnormal tone and/or coordination (flaccidity or spasticity), as indicated
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess gross functional strength with manual muscle testing (MMT) or handheld dynamometer (if tone is normal), including trunk strength and core stability, as abdominal muscle strength may be reduced due to chronic bloating and tenderness. Assess handgrip strength with dynamometer
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess general posture in sitting and standing and note any asymmetry
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess trunk and bilateral upper and lower extremity ROM with goniometry or grossly by observation of movement
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess bilateral upper and lower extremity deep tendon reflexes and protective righting responses to challenges in balance
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation to light touch and proprioception in bilateral upper and lower extremities as indicated
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –The IBS-Quality  of Life tool. This is a self-administered questionnaire consisting of 34 items, each with a 5-point response scale. The total score is converted to a scale of 0 (high QOL) to 100 (low QOL)(4)ShortForm-12  Physical Component Score (SF-12  PCS) and Short Form-12  Mental Component Score (SF-12  MCS)(13) –The IBS-SSS  provides a simple method of rating symptoms and monitoring their progress(5) –Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale is a 14-item questionnaire to measure the individual’s level of anxiety and depression
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess patient’s ability to follow commands and attend to specific tasks. Is patient alert and oriented x 4? Describe the patient’s mood or affect

other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the referring physician

Patients with this diagnosis may be at an increased risk for falls due to their potential for reduced ability to make it to the bathroom in a timely manner, especially in individuals with comorbidities that impair their balance and functional mobility; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies

Clinicians should always follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and the referring physician’s orders. Contact the referring physician regarding any physical activity restrictions including resistance training, type of physical activity, etc. due to the patient’s comorbid medical conditions
Patients with IBS may wish to avoid exercise on “bad” days. Ensure that the patient has easy access to a restroom during treatment sessions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Medical diagnosis is based on the NICE clinical guidelines Individuals with IBS can benefit from physical therapy treatment intervention to address secondary impairments and disability associated with IBS such as reduced physical functioning (often due to insufficient physical activity), impaired core/trunk strength that contributes to functional deficits (e.g., posture, performance of ADLs) and reduced QOL, or impaired gait and dynamic balance
assessment plan of care.rule out: Inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease, microscopic colitis, collagenous colitis), colorectal/bowel cancer, celiac disease, lactose intolerance, malabsorption disorders, GI infection, ovarian cancer, thyroid dysfunction, bowel obstruction
prognosis: There is no cure for IBS and no consensus on the optimum treatment. Treatment interventions are based on controlling the individual’s symptoms(7)

Authors of a longitudinal research study in Taiwan found that individuals with IBS are at an increased risk of developing colorectal neoplasms(16) –Participants were 40 years of age or older who had been included in a colorectal screening program from January 1999 to December 2004. Follow-up  was performed until 2009
In a study conducted in Japan, investigators found that females and persons with lower scores on the mental component summary (MCS) of the SF-8  generally have poor response to treatment (24)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physician specialists (e.g., family practice, gastroenterology, internal medicine); nutritionist/ dietitian; behavioral psychologist/clinician; recreational therapist; aquatic exercise therapist; yoga instructor, occupational therapist for ADL training
other considerations: Mindfulness-based  therapy may be an effective method to decrease IBS symptoms, based on a quasi-experimental  study (n = 36) in Iran(10) –Subjects were randomly divided into 2 experimental groups (cognitive-behavioral  treatment and mindfulness-based treatment) and a control group without IBS –Cognitive-behavioral  therapy took place once a week for 2½ hours per session for 8 weeks. Mindfulness-based  therapy took place once a week for 2-hour  group sessions for 8 weeks –A significant decrease in IBS symptoms occurred in both experimental groups compared to the control group, although mindfulness-based  therapy was more effective at reducing symptoms
Diets with low levels of fermentable oligo-,  di-, and monosaccharides and polyols (FODMAPs) can significantly reduce abdominal pain and bloating as well as reduce pain related to IBS (26)

Individuals with IBS frequently have lower self-esteem  and may benefit from psychological therapy(17) –Researchers from Iran found that patients with IBS have higher levels of poor appetite, difficulty sleeping, thoughts of death/dying, and feelings of guilt compared with those without IBS(19)

Acupuncture therapy may improve symptoms of diarrhea-predominant  IBS compared to use of drug therapy and has fewer side effects. Acupuncture points used included the ST25, ST36, ST37, SP6, GV20, and EX-HN3  (21)

Herbal remedies that include a mixture of B. carterii , Z. officinale , and A. millefolium  have been effective in reducing IBS symptoms and improving depression scores and anxiety in patients with IBS (23)
treatment summary: Physical therapy guidelines for specifically treating IBS symptoms are lacking. Comorbidities will likely influence the need for targeted treatment and should be addressed per physician’s orders. Follow general guidelines for exercise prescription(3)

Therapeutic exercises may be needed to address impairments noted in strength, flexibility, and/or endurance. Functional training may be indicated to reduce deficits noted in posture, balance, and/or gait

Participation in a “micro-physiotherapy”  program can significantly improve symptoms associated with IBS, according to a study. Micro-physiotherapy  was defined in this study as performing micro-palpatory  examination(s) to identify osteopathic lesions, as well as performing a micro-massage  to stimulate healing (27)

Low to moderate physical exercise has been show to reduce symptoms associated with IBS. Physiological factors that promote improved symptoms are a result of the reversal of anti- to pro-inflammatory cytokines and facilitating blood redox homeostasis (30)

A six-week  aerobic training program utilizing a treadmill has been shown to significantly improve severity symptoms of IBS and overall quality of life (31) –Twentywomen with mild to moderate symptoms of IBS were randomized to either the treadmill group (n = 10) or control group (n = 10) –Those participating in the treadmill group received 6- weeks of 30 minute treadmill training exercises 3x/ week. Control group were asked to perform usual daily activities –. Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Abdominal pain, bloating, and IBS symptoms related to diarrhea and/or constipationReduced frequency and severity of symptoms, and reduced negative impact on QoLFunctional training _ Interventions to increase physical activity to improve long-term effects associated with IBS symptoms and psychological symptoms (32)Gradually progress frequency, duration, and intensity of exercise to recommended levelsProvide patient with simple instructions for home exercise .

maintenance or prevention: Continue maintenance program of therapeutic physical activity
patient education: Wolters Kluwer Health UpToDatewebsite, “Patient Information: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (Beyond the Basics),” http://www.uptodate.com/contents/irritable-bowel-syndrome-beyond-the-basics Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
